column3: My dad's always been a famous actor, so I've grown up with that, and with the lifestyle. In a way, I think I thrive on the insecurity that comes with it. Not in my private life - I like to believe that my friendships and my relationships are strong.
A lot of people come to Los Angeles and think that they're going to be famous, just like that.

I have a theory that if you're famous more years than you're not famous, then you get a little nutty.
Anything that's of any use, famous people get hold of it and take it for themselves and it gets a bad rap.
My daughter couldn't care less about me being famous. She finds it revolting and, like a lot of teenagers, is virtually allergic to me. That started at 12 and hasn't gone anywhere yet.
The family is very important. They make me feel good always because if I won, when I started to be famous, the relationship never changed with my friends and family.

I don't understand anyone thinking I'm sexy at all. I don't get it because, growing up as a kid, I wasn't. I was like a dork, fat, so for me it's really weird. I became famous in Australia when I was 18, and I was still a little bit chubby.

I went from being totally unknown and never acting professionally to being in a major movie and being very famous. It all happened so quickly, I didn't have any time to work things out. It's been pretty scary at times.
It's not like I'm that wildly famous that it's disrupted my lifestyle in some way.

I never thought being famous would be wonderful, but my limited exposure to celebrity has shown me the dark side big-time.

And I found that I didn't believe that. But what the emotions really are, I don't have an alternative theory.

I don't want to be famous for being famous.
